author: By Maria Cramer
title: Top U.S. Lands Official Served Unlawfully for Over a Year, a Federal Judge Rules
description: A federal judge in Montana ordered William Perry Pendley, whose appointment was not confirmed by the Senate, to leave the position.
content: A federal judge in Montana has ordered William Perry Pendley, the acting director of the Bureau of Land Management, to leave the position after finding that he had served unlawfully as acting director for 424 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: North Carolina: An empty campus says a lot about the state of the race.
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — I have visited this charming college town too many times to count over the years, sometimes to cover campaigns and more often for fun. But I’ve never seen Chapel Hill as quiet as I found it last weekend.
content: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — I have visited this charming college town too many times to count over the years, sometimes to cover campaigns and more often for fun. But I’ve never seen Chapel Hill as quiet as I found it last weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: November’s election could hinge on the voting process itself.
description: Many Americans watch fireworks displays on Independence Day, eat turkey on Thanksgiving and, on Election Day, head to a school gymnasium, library or senior center to cast a ballot for their favorite presidential candidate.
content: Many Americans watch fireworks displays on Independence Day, eat turkey on Thanksgiving and, on Election Day, head to a school gymnasium, library or senior center to cast a ballot for their favorite presidential candidate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Makiko Inoue
title: Japan Is Paying Firms to Make Things at Home. But China’s Pull Is Still Strong.
description: Japan is attempting a delicate balancing act as the pandemic has underlined the risks of the world’s economic reliance on Beijing.
content: TOKYO — Until July, the Japanese household goods company Iris Ohyama had always made its line of masks at its two factories in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Rebecca R. Ruiz
title: Barrett, with children in tow, is seen leaving her Indiana home.
description: Judge Amy Coney Barrett and members of her family left their home in South Bend, Ind., shortly after noon Eastern time, several hours before President Trump was expected to name her to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on the Supreme Court.
content: Judge Amy Coney Barrett and members of her family left their home in South Bend, Ind., shortly after noon Eastern time, several hours before President Trump was expected to name her to replace Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg on the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Karen Crouse
title: As the French Open Begins, Confusion and Fears About Coronavirus Dominate
description: This tournament was supposed to represent the next stage for the comeback of tennis, with fans in the stands and more freedom for the players. It is not turning out that way.
content: The sports world’s dance with coronavirus lands in Paris this weekend, at the French Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Coronavirus Survey Halted After Workers Faced Racial Slurs, Officials Say
description: Workers were followed, videotaped and threatened in confrontations across Minnesota, the state Department of Health said.
content: A coronavirus survey in Minnesota was stopped after multiple cases of residents “intimidating and shouting racial and ethnic slurs” at public health workers who had been going door to door, the state Department of Health said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: ‘Schitt’s Creek’ Star, and His Fans, Are Taking Indigenous Studies
description: Dan Levy suggested in an Instagram post that his fans study Canadian Indigenous history along with him. About 64,000 people signed up.
content: TORONTO — Before the Canadian show “Schitt’s Creek” swept the Emmys this month and catapulted its creator, Dan Levy, into Hollywood’s stratosphere, he announced that he was going back to school, and wanted his fans to join him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Barrett’s Record: A Conservative Who Would Push the Supreme Court to the Right
description: As an appeals court judge, Judge Barrett has issued opinions that have reflected those of her mentor, Justice Antonin Scalia, but with few of his occasional liberal rulings.
content: WASHINGTON — Judge Amy Coney Barrett, President Trump’s pick for the Supreme Court, has compiled an almost uniformly conservative voting record in cases touching on abortion, gun rights, discrimination and immigration. If she is confirmed, she would move the court slightly but firmly to the right, making compromise less likely and putting at risk the right to abortion established in Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 26, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 26, 2020.
content: An article in today’s paper about a series of killings on Long Island nearly a decade ago misstated the status of Thomas J. Spota’s sentencing for conspiracy. He has been convicted, but has not yet been sentenced or served time in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Raymond Zhong
title: U.S. Places Restrictions on China’s Leading Chip Maker
description: The export controls follow a review in which the United States concluded that Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation’s chips may be used by the Chinese military.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has placed new restrictions on exports to Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation, China’s most advanced maker of computer chips, a measure that could deepen the technology conflict between China and the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Paris Suspect Said Attack Was Aimed at Paper That Mocked Islam’s Prophet
description: An 18-year-old immigrant from Pakistan was arrested on Friday after the stabbing of two people near the former offices of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, which was targeted in a 2015 terrorist attack.
content: PARIS — The suspect in the stabbing of two people outside the former Paris office of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo has confessed and said his attack was directed at the publication because it printed cartoons mocking the Prophet Muhammad, a French judicial official said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: China Gives Unproven Covid-19 Vaccines to Thousands, With Risks Unknown
description: Drug company workers, government officials and others have been injected outside the usual testing process. More will be soon, bewildering experts who worry about potential ill effects.
content: First, workers at state-owned companies got dosed. Then government officials and vaccine company staff. Up next: teachers, supermarket employees and people traveling to risky areas abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your New Favorite Carrot Cake
description: Make Yossy Arefi’s recipe with a tangy lemon glaze.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Yossy Arefi’s one-bowl carrot loaf cake with tangy lemon glaze (above), Sue Li’s Taiwanese meefun and Kay Chun’s baked risotto with greens and peas. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kay Nolan
title: Wisconsin: Milwaukee tries to reverse a troubling trend in voter registration.
description: MILWAUKEE — The Milwaukee Brewers’ famous racing sausage mascots rambled about the sprawling parking lot of the Miller Park baseball stadium for a few hours on Tuesday, but they weren’t there to promote sausage or baseball: It was National Voter Registration Day.
content: MILWAUKEE — The Milwaukee Brewers’ famous racing sausage mascots rambled about the sprawling parking lot of the Miller Park baseball stadium for a few hours on Tuesday, but they weren’t there to promote sausage or baseball: It was National Voter Registration Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: With Outdoor Dining Comes Outdoor Noise. What Can You Do?
description: The city’s guidance for outdoor dining allows bars and restaurants to set up seating on private property without a permit. But they still must comply with the noise code.
content: Q: The bedroom window of my Upper East Side co-op apartment overlooks the rear yard of another building that has a bar on the ground floor. The bar previously used the rear yard for trash and recycling. But since restaurants reopened for outdoor dining, it has been using the space for seating, adding a lot of late night noise to the area (and my bedroom). Can a bar make any outdoor space into seating for customers?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Tasmania Whale Rescue Ends With 108 Saved and Over 300 Dead
description: The whale beaching, one of the largest strandings ever recorded globally, prompted a five-day rescue effort.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — Wildlife officials in the Australian state of Tasmania began disposing of hundreds of dead pilot whales on Saturday after ending rescue attempts in one of the largest incidents of whale beaching ever recorded globally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Trump Again Says He Would Welcome a ‘Smooth’ Transition. But He Has Conditions.
description: The president warned his supporters of Democratic schemes to “cheat” their way to victory in November and said, “We’re not going to stand for it.”
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump said Friday night that he would welcome “a smooth, beautiful transition” of power after the election in November but that he would lose only if Democrats cheated — and that “we’re not going to stand for it” if they did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Astead W. Herndon
title: Biden, With Strong Polls, May Have More at Stake in the Debate: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: President Trump’s Supreme Court pick was leaked 24 hours before his official announcement. The Supreme Court nomination and next week’s first presidential debate both have the chance to alter the 2020 race.
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Keith Hufnagel, Pro Skateboarder and Entrepreneur, Dies at 46
description: He soared over treacherous streets on his board before opening a streetwear store that grew into the popular brand Huf.
content: Keith Hufnagel, a professional skateboarder who grew a San Francisco streetwear store, Huf, into a global apparel company by the same name, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 46.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Barr has brought the D.O.J. closer to the White House than it has been in a half-century, historians say.
description: When the top federal prosecutor in Washington recently accused the local police of arresting protesters without probable cause, Attorney General William P. Barr stepped in.
content: When the top federal prosecutor in Washington recently accused the local police of arresting protesters without probable cause, Attorney General William P. Barr stepped in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Seligson
title: The New Unsexy Sexy Marketplace
description: Earning money online by selling intimate objects that aren’t obviously sexual (including emotions).
content: Pornography is the most common form of sexual experience available online — so common, perhaps, that a market for rarer intimacies has emerged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Confused About Voting? Here Are Some Easy Tips
description: This year’s election will be a little different from past ones, given the pandemic, but with planning and a few precautions, voting shouldn’t be any more difficult.
content: We’re in the middle of a pandemic. You’re busy. Things are confusing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Trump is expected to announce his Supreme Court pick at 5 p.m.
description: Here are the daily schedules of the presidential and vice-presidential candidates for Saturday, Sept. 26. All times are Eastern time.
content: Here are the daily schedules of the presidential and vice-presidential candidates for Saturday, Sept. 26. All times are Eastern time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: Colleges Are Hiring Their Own Students as Covid-19 Safety Influencers
description: Like, subscribe, and wear a mask.
content: Erin Marquino, a junior at the University of Missouri, sits in a hammock, working on her laptop in a photo she posted on Instagram in early September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Hurdle
title: Pennsylvania: In a county Trump flipped, Democrats seek voters willing to flip back.
description: WILKES-BARRE, Pa. — Democrats are hoping to reverse Mr. Trump’s resounding win four years ago in northeastern Pennsylvania’s Luzerne County, but they have a mountain to climb.
content: WILKES-BARRE, Pa. — Democrats are hoping to reverse Mr. Trump’s resounding win four years ago in northeastern Pennsylvania’s Luzerne County, but they have a mountain to climb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
title: This Carousel Has Had Quite a Ride. Will Anyone in Japan Save It?
description: The 113-year-old merry-go-round, which arrived in Tokyo after stints in Germany and Coney Island, is now in storage, its fate uncertain in a country that tends to preserve only the very old.
content: TOKYO — From the shrines of Nikko and the temples of Kyoto to the castles of Matsumoto and Himeji, the Japanese are fiercely proud of the country’s centuries-old monuments of cultural heritage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez
title: Texas: Does Biden actually have a shot at winning? The answer is a tossup.
description: HOUSTON — It’s been a long time since a Democrat won Texas in a presidential race. “Disco Duck” ruled the airwaves and “All the President’s Men” was all the cinematic rage the last time it happened. The year was 1976, when Texans selected Jimmy Carter over Gerald R. Ford.
content: HOUSTON — It’s been a long time since a Democrat won Texas in a presidential race. “Disco Duck” ruled the airwaves and “All the President’s Men” was all the cinematic rage the last time it happened. The year was 1976, when Texans selected Jimmy Carter over Gerald R. Ford.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Elizabeth Dias
title: Barrett Clerked for Scalia. Conservatives Hope She’ll Follow His Path.
description: For years, the conservative movement has been searching for someone who could lead American jurisprudence to the right with the kind of intellectual rigor that conservatives say made Justice Antonin Scalia so effective for decades.
content: WASHINGTON — By the time she graduated at the top of her Notre Dame Law School class in 1997, besting 187 students, Amy Coney Barrett was already a legal superstar. She would soon go on to clerk at the Supreme Court and, not long after, return to teach at her alma mater, admired by faculty and students alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canadian Police Charge Man With Faking Terrorist Activity
description: The man, Shehroze Chaudhry, created a political storm in Canada with his assertions that he participated in atrocities by ISIS in Syria.
content: OTTAWA — The police in Canada have arrested a Toronto-area man who asserted he was an ISIS executioner, accusing him of perpetrating a hoax that he was involved in terrorist activities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio and Judith Levitt
title: Remembering Ruth Bader Ginsburg
description: Photos capture the Supreme Court justice’s life and legacy, from her Brooklyn girlhood to a late-in-life turn as the Notorious R.B.G.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Adam Liptak
title: For conservatives, Barrett checks all the boxes.
description: Two years ago, after nominating Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court, President Trump strongly hinted that his choice for the next opening would be a former law professor he had named to a federal appeals court the year before: Judge Amy Coney Barrett.
content: Two years ago, after nominating Brett M. Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court, President Trump strongly hinted that his choice for the next opening would be a former law professor he had named to a federal appeals court the year before: Judge Amy Coney Barrett.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Kaitlin Gillespie
title: A Day of Protest in Portland as ‘Proud Boys’ Converge on the City
description: Ralliers gathered at three locations as a large police presence mostly kept them apart. The Oregon governor had declared an emergency in advance, but few arrests were made.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — Hundreds of law enforcement agents swept across Portland on Saturday, making targeted arrests, shutting down intersections and seizing weapons in a largely successful effort to keep opposing political rallies across the city from erupting into violent conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Stephenson
title: Arizona: A Donald Trump Jr. event is full of people and conspiracy theories.
description: CHANDLER, Ariz. — More than 800 people lined up early on Tuesday morning to see Donald Trump Jr., the president’s eldest son, and Charlie Kirk, the 26-year-old founder of Turning Point USA, speak at a hotel here.
content: CHANDLER, Ariz. — More than 800 people lined up early on Tuesday morning to see Donald Trump Jr., the president’s eldest son, and Charlie Kirk, the 26-year-old founder of Turning Point USA, speak at a hotel here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: For U.K.’s Boris Johnson, Hardball Tactics Seem the Only Way to a Brexit Deal
description: With a combative style, Mr. Johnson has pointedly avoided comparisons to Theresa May, his predecessor. But will his strategy yield a deal?
content: LONDON — Britain was at sea, lost in a “fog of self-doubt.” It had dithered only to retreat. And in its pursuit of Brexit, it exuded a “conspicuous infirmity of purpose.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Michael Levenson
title: Before Trump’s Supreme Court announcement, Biden accuses him of dividing the country.
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. escalated his attacks on President Trump on Saturday, accusing him of dividing the country into “blue cities” and “red cities.” And in a newly televised interview, Mr. Biden compared the president to Joseph Goebbels, Nazi Germany’s minister of propaganda.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. escalated his attacks on President Trump on Saturday, accusing him of dividing the country into “blue cities” and “red cities.” And in a newly televised interview, Mr. Biden compared the president to Joseph Goebbels, Nazi Germany’s minister of propaganda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bruenig
title: Amy Coney Barrett and the New, Old Anti-Catholicism
description: Critics of Trump’s Supreme Court nominee argue that pious Catholics are a problem for liberalism. They have a point.
content: We live in an era where everything is shocking and nothing is surprising. Every major item of news over the last week or so — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s passing, the inevitable Republican hustle to replace her on the eve of an extremely contentious election with the nomination of Amy Coney Barrett and the sectarian clashes over her faith — arrived as a jolt to a fragile, anxious nation. And yet all of it was long in the making — the conflict over Judge Barrett’s religion most of all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derek M. Norman
title: Police, Protests and Violence: How Times Video Experts Examine a Scene
description: In analyzing footage involving fatalities or accusations of brutality, the Visual Investigations unit pursues the truth, frame by frame.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Here’s What 4 of Our Reporters Are Watching as Voting Begins to Unfold
description: Mail-in ballots, legal challenges, voter education: Our journalists discussed their thinking about what is shaping up to be a fiercely contested, multiday election.
content: Perhaps never before in American history has the act of voting been so closely scrutinized before a presidential election. A pandemic, partisan attacks on voting rights and a White House incumbent falsely warning of fraud have put extraordinary pressure on the democratic process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Church That Hosted Emmett Till’s Funeral Is Designated ‘Endangered’
description: Roberts Temple Church of God in Christ in Chicago, where thousands paid their respects to the murdered teenager in 1955, was placed on a new list of endangered historic places in the United States.
content: The Chicago church where thousands flocked to the funeral of Emmett Till — the 14-year-old who was brutally tortured and murdered in Mississippi in 1955 — has been placed on a national list of endangered historic sites.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Minneapolis officials said they would defund the police. Some now regret that pledge.
description: Over three months ago, a majority of the Minneapolis City Council pledged to defund the city’s Police Department, making a powerful statement that reverberated across the country. It shook up Capitol Hill and the presidential race, shocked residents, delighted activists and changed the trajectory of efforts to overhaul the police during a crucial window of tumult and political opportunity.
content: Over three months ago, a majority of the Minneapolis City Council pledged to defund the city’s Police Department, making a powerful statement that reverberated across the country. It shook up Capitol Hill and the presidential race, shocked residents, delighted activists and changed the trajectory of efforts to overhaul the police during a crucial window of tumult and political opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Bazelon
title: Amy Coney Barrett Is No Ruth Bader Ginsburg
description: When it comes to the Supreme Court, we’ve been to this identity politics movie before.
content: President Trump’s promise to name a woman to replace Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who died on Sept. 18 at 87, was cynical and insulting to the millions of women who view the late Supreme Court justice as a feminist icon. Senator John Barrasso, a Wyoming Republican, praised the decision as a “powerful positive statement” to young women, who would embrace the president’s nominee as a “role model.” The message to women is clear: Nothing to see here, ladies! One of you is as good as any other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Edelheit
title: What a Sold-Out N.F.L. Game Is Like in 2020
description: The Jaguars drew a socially distanced capacity crowd for Thursday night’s game against the Dolphins, as football fans sought a bit of normalcy.
content: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — The “Duval” cheers, the lights and the Jacksonville Jaguars were all in action again, but it was clear that Week 3 at TIAA Bank Field was different from my last visit, in 2019. When I attended that hot, early fall home opener, I talked to strangers seated next to me, stood in line close to people, and enjoyed the battery-operated fans that blew air in our faces to last with over 100-degree temperatures inside the stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: A Man Died After Eating a Bag of Black Licorice Every Day
description: Doctors at Massachusetts General Hospital said the unusual case highlighted the risk of consuming too much glycyrrhizic acid, which is found in black licorice.
content: He had no history of heart problems. He walked his dog regularly and worked a physically demanding job as a construction worker, according to his doctors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Cleansing of the Soul
description: Kristian House leads an outdoor workout.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — There’s something rhythmic and earwormish about this Kristian House grid (for me, the catchy solving tune was “My Favorite Things”). I suppose it’s something about all the two- and three-syllable entries making the puzzle pop instead of just supporting flashy, monster spans. Three debuts, some more rarities and some very well-clued misdirects made this a sparkling solve and a bit of a challenge for me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Schram
title: Lightning Have Championship in Sights After Winning Third Straight Game
description: Kevin Shattenkirk scored on the power play in overtime to give Tampa Bay a 5-4 win and a lead of three games to one over Dallas.
content: EDMONTON, Alberta — The Tampa Bay Lightning could be less than 24 hours away from hoisting the Stanley Cup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Lee and Chris Jones
title: Fake Guns, Fictional Battles, Real Uniforms: Inside the Immersive World of MilSim
description: Veterans, gamers, history buffs and gun enthusiasts are shelling out to take part in military simulations.
content: In February, a group of several hundred military enthusiasts gathered to play-fight in Clovis, Calif., at the foot of the Sierra Nevada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: In Isolating Times, Can Robo-Pets Provide Comfort?
description: As seniors find themselves cut off from loved ones during the pandemic, some are turning to automated animals for company.
content: When Linda Spangler asked her mother, in a video chat, what she would like as gift for her 92nd birthday, the response came promptly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Meaning of Amy Coney Barrett
description: Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s likely successor could become a different kind of three-initialed icon.
content: Ruth Bader Ginsburg became, late in her long and illustrious career, more than just a Supreme Court justice. She was a cultural symbol, a human distillation of an era and a cause, her special celebrity rooted in the way her fight for legal opportunities for women combined with her own extraordinary success in the spheres she opened up. As a jurist Ginsburg was one of the court’s four liberals, important but not singular; as the Notorious R.B.G., she embodied liberal feminism, a history of struggle and achievement condensed into three initials and one life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: To Beat Trump, Mock Him
description: The lesson from pro-democracy fighters abroad: Humor deflates authoritarian rulers.
content: Can critics of President Trump learn something from pro-democracy movements in other countries?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck
title: Democrats Don’t Want to Get Personal in Debate Over Barrett
description: Joseph Biden and other Democrats are wary of criticism of Judge Amy Coney Barrett that could be perceived as personal. They will focus on the real-world impact she might have as a Supreme Court justice on health care and access to abortion.
content: For Joseph R. Biden Jr. and the Democratic Party that he now leads, the selection of Judge Amy Coney Barrett by President Trump on Saturday puts a name and a face to the urgent threat they believe a 6-3 conservative majority on the Supreme Court poses to decades of progressive laws and protections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: Inside eBay’s Cockroach Cult: The Ghastly Story of a Stalking Scandal
description: “People are basically good” was eBay’s founding principle. But in the deranged summer of 2019, prosecutors say, a campaign to terrorize a blogger crawled out of a dark place in the corporate soul.
content: Veronica Zea is pretty sure that before showing up to work at eBay in the spring of 2017, she used the site only once. She bought a surfing poster. It ended up in her closet.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Pentagon Leaders Worry Trump Will Drag Military Into Election
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 26, 2020.
content: “The Pentagon plans for war with Canada and a zombie apocalypse, but they don’t want to plan for a contested election. These are huge questions that have an impact on the reputation of the institution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Nicholas Fandos and Daniel Victor
title: The Judiciary Committee will hold hearings starting Oct. 12. Here is what’s next.
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee will hold confirmation hearings for four consecutive days beginning Oct. 12.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican majority leader, has already vowed that the Senate will vote on President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee by the end of the year, though he has not made clear whether that will happen before Election Day, Nov. 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer, Alexander Burns and Katie Glueck
title: A High-Stakes Test for Joe Biden’s Love of Senate Tradition
description: He reveres custom and recognizes the courts’ essential role in shaping a policy agenda. Those dual instincts have perhaps never been in greater conflict as they are in this Supreme Court fight.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. was trying to demonstrate the lasting power of the federal judiciary. So he did the math.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: In Colorado, Fiery Political Novice Aims for a Seat in the House
description: Lauren Boebert, a Glock-packing newcomer to politics, upset a Republican incumbent, but increasing scrutiny and a well-funded challenger have made her a top target for Democrats.
content: LOMA, Colo. — Lauren Boebert, the feisty hard-right Republican House candidate, had just finished regaling a crowd clad in red, white and blue at a livestock sale barn here on the Western Slope with dire warnings that “our country is on the line” in the coming election and “if we lose America, we lose our freedoms.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Jesse McKinley
title: Trump Attacked Rochester Protesters. Not All Local Republicans Agree.
description: In Western New York, the president’s vilification of Black Lives Matter protests has forced candidates to decide whether to line up behind him.
content: ROCHESTER, N.Y. — It did not take long for President Trump to wade into the civil unrest that seized the city over the death of Daniel Prude, a Black man who died of suffocation after Rochester police officers placed a hood over his head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Knoll
title: Miro Heiskanen Is Dallas’s Do-Everything Defenseman
description: Heiskanen, 21, leads all players at that position in points this postseason and has impressed greats like Nicklas Lidstrom with his play.
content: Dallas Stars defenseman Miro Heiskanen may be understated, but his play speaks for him with all the force, dynamism and range of a concert choir.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel and Nick Corasaniti
title: These nine state counties could swing the election.
description: Love it or hate it, the Electoral College is the turnstile to the White House, and that means that a handful of states will swallow up most of the attention on Election Day and, if necessary, in the days that follow as ballots are counted.
content: Love it or hate it, the Electoral College is the turnstile to the White House, and that means that a handful of states will swallow up most of the attention on Election Day and, if necessary, in the days that follow as ballots are counted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Leader of India Says Country’s Vaccine Industry Will ‘Help All Humanity’
description: A study offered an explanation for children’s ability to fight off the virus. The lockdown in Melbourne, Australia, is being further eased.
content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India said in his annual United Nations General Assembly address Saturday that his country’s vast vaccine-production industry would serve the world  in fighting the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Emma Bubola
title: Pasta, Wine and Inflatable Pools: How Amazon Conquered Italy in the Pandemic
description: The e-commerce giant had struggled to gain a foothold in a society that prefers to shop in person, with cash, but now Italians are hooked on online shopping.
content: NAPLES, Italy — Ludovica Tomaciello had never shopped on Amazon before being trapped at her parents’ house in March during Italy’s coronavirus lockdown. Bored one afternoon scrolling TikTok, she spotted hair scrunchies that she then tracked down and ordered on Amazon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon read the current mood.
content: ACROSTIC — I made a mess of this solve, but the excerpt is out of a terrifically acerbic book that I once read and loved — it’s on a shelf in my basement right now, reminding me of college when my tastes ran to Dorothy Parker, William S. Burroughs and today’s author, Ambrose Bierce. Shades of social commentary, all of them dark, all of them quite apropos to the moment in time that we’re now navigating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Michael Lonsdale, a Bond Villain and Much More, Dies at 89
description: He was best known to many as Hugo Drax in “Moonraker.” But he also worked with a Who’s Who of directors including Truffaut, Spielberg and Marguerite Duras.
content: Michael Lonsdale, a versatile veteran of French cinema who was known abroad for his villains and antiheroes, including the sad-eyed and subtly psychotic Hugo Drax in the James Bond film “Moonraker” and the mysterious intelligence broker in Steven Spielberg’s “Munich,” died on Monday at his home in Paris. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: What Is the Future of Black Appalachia?
description: We spoke to the curators of a cultural center in rural Virginia who have redoubled their efforts to help shape the future of Black Appalachia.
content: On a warm July day, Ron and Jill Carson sat in a former one-room schoolhouse in Pennington Gap, Va., that until 1965 was the only primary school in town for Black children. The first seven years of Mr. Carson’s education took place in that building, which was built by his great-great-grandmother in 1939.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Pandemic Will ‘Take Our Women 10 Years Back’ in the Workplace
description: Improvements in gender equality in the workplace may be another casualty of the coronavirus, as women find their place in the work force more at risk.
content: As if working mothers did not have enough to worry about, experts are now sounding the alarm that progress toward gender equality may be the latest in a long list of casualties of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Brushing Off Criticism, China’s Xi Calls Policies in Xinjiang ‘Totally Correct’
description: Mr. Xi made the remarks at a meeting on the region of western China, suggesting that the Communist Party remains committed to drastically changing Uighurs and other Muslim minorities.
content: Brushing aside condemnation from Western powers, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, called his policies in the ethnically divided region of Xinjiang a “totally correct” success, and vowed more efforts to imprint Chinese national identity “deep in the soul” of Uighurs and other largely Muslim minorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Sheinbaum
title: Pandemic Appropriate Wedding Gifts
description: Wedding pros and seasoned guests share a few of their go-to gifts that newlyweds can enjoy now while quarantining.
content: Along with many couples’ 2020 wedding plans, gifts and registries during the coronavirus pandemic may look a little different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Besha Rodell
title: In Melbourne, Springtime Ushers in a New Sense of Hope
description: As our Covid-19 restrictions ease, the mood of the city feels like the weather.
content: There are blossoms on the trees in Melbourne and days of cold rain and blustering wind, but also days of sweet-smelling breezes and warm sunshine. This has been a hard year for my hometown, which is still undergoing one of the world’s strictest and longest lockdowns because of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: How a Pledge to Dismantle the Minneapolis Police Collapsed
description: When a majority of City Council members promised to “end policing as we know it” after George Floyd’s killing, they became a case study in how idealistic calls for structural change can falter.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Over three months ago, a majority of the Minneapolis City Council pledged to defund the city’s police department, making a powerful statement that reverberated across the country. It shook up Capitol Hill and the presidential race, shocked residents, delighted activists and changed the trajectory of efforts to overhaul the police during a crucial window of tumult and political opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Full Transcript: Read Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s Remarks
description: President Trump announced on Saturday that he would nominate Judge Barrett to the Supreme Court to fill the vacancy left by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
content: President Trump announced Saturday afternoon that he would nominate Judge Amy Coney Barrett to the Supreme Court, setting off a politically explosive scramble to confirm a deeply conservative jurist before Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Playing With Food
description: Alex Eaton-Salners provides the ingredients for a sumptuous Sunday solve.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This grid harkened me back to the simpler days of 2019 when Alex Eaton-Salners made a Sunday puzzle for us with a bunch of cryptic bird clues. Guess what? That one was inspired by this one, and now I’m trying to think of some other subjects that would be fun with this treatment for next year, if we make it. Cocktails, maybe. Funny note for fans of this constructor: Can you believe that this one and that one, “Bird Play,” are his only big Sunday grids? I was surprised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Dr. Rebecca Shadowen, Expert in Infectious Diseases, Dies at 62
description: Dr. Shadowen, ill with the coronavirus, continued to attend meetings from her hospital bed. She eventually died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The dogma lives loudly within you’: Revisiting Barrett’s confirmation hearing.
description: A remark from Senator Dianne Feinstein during Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s Court of Appeals confirmation hearing in 2017 became a badge of defiance for conservatives battling what they saw as anti-religion bias by Democratic lawmakers.
content: A remark from Senator Dianne Feinstein during Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s Court of Appeals confirmation hearing in 2017 became a badge of defiance for conservatives battling what they saw as anti-religion bias by Democratic lawmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Judge Orders New Trial for Gigi Jordan in Son’s Killing
description: Ms. Jordan was found guilty of manslaughter for poisoning her 8-year-old son, but a federal judge ruled that her right to a public trial had been violated.
content: A federal judge in Manhattan on Friday ordered a new trial for Gigi Jordan, who was convicted of killing her 8-year-old autistic son after mounting a novel defense based on her belief that her first husband would murder her and her second would victimize the boy after her death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Gray
title: Michigan: Enthusiasm runs high as early voting begins.
description: DETROIT — Sharletta Johnson is not one to curse, but she made an exception Thursday morning, the first day Michiganders could begin dropping off absentee ballots with local clerks.
content: DETROIT — Sharletta Johnson is not one to curse, but she made an exception Thursday morning, the first day Michiganders could begin dropping off absentee ballots with local clerks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board and Damon Winter
title: Trump’s Messy Divorce From New York
description: Has a president ever been so at odds with his hometown?
content: “If somebody hits you, you’ve got to hit ’em back five times harder than they ever thought possible,” Donald Trump said in a speech outlining his philosophy on business in 2012. “You’ve got to get even. Get even.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Adam Goldman
title: Justice Dept. Documents Highlight Criticisms of Mueller Inquiry
description: The attorney general provided information on two matters to President Trump’s allies that was meant to damage the F.B.I.’s Russia investigation and the special counsel’s office.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department this week turned over to allies of President Trump documents that appeared to undermine aspects of the investigation into the campaign’s ties with Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: The Virus Sent Droves to a Small Town. Suddenly, It’s Not So Small.
description: The population boomed in Winhall, Vt., as people tried to get away from Covid-19 hot spots. Bear complaints are up. Plumbers are booked until Christmas. And the dump is “sheer pandemonium.”
content: WINHALL, Vt. — From his post at the town dump, Scott Bushee spent the summer observing his new neighbors, transplants who pulled into his compound with heads full of rustic fantasy and license plates from New York and New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Nicholas Fandos
title: Trump Announces Barrett as Supreme Court Nominee, Describing Her as Heir to Scalia
description: In choosing Judge Amy Coney Barrett, the president opted for the candidate most likely to thrill his conservative base and outrage his liberal opponents.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump introduced Judge Amy Coney Barrett as his nominee to the Supreme Court on Saturday, presenting her as a champion of conservative judicial principles and igniting a partisan and ideological battle to confirm her before the election in just 38 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: This Basketball-Loving Poet Resists Categorization
description: Fresh off the success of his play “Barber Shop Chronicles,” Inua Ellams has a new book out, “The Half God of Rainfall,” about a son of Zeus who dominates on the courts.
content: Last year was a big one for the poet, playwright and performer Inua Ellams.
source.name: The New York Times
